div1.p: UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT WESTERN DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON NORTHERN DIVISION
In the Matter of the Petition of THOMAS L. THURSTON for a Writ of Habeas Corpus } No. 3128
MEMORANDUM BRIEF.
In oral argument counsel has submitted two points to the consideration of the court.
First, that no proper commitment was issued upon which the defendant, a prisoner at McNeil Island, can properly be confined.

Second, that the judgment entered in this case is fatally defective and void by reason of the fact that it omits to mention, either by reference to section or descriptive terms the crime for which the defendant was punished.
The respondent has filed herein his answer and stip- ulation, and to the facts recited therein the attention of the court is directed

Counsel for petitioner has submitted in oral argu- ment and in writing a memorandum referring to Section 1028 of the Revised Statutes, found at page 335, volume 2 Fed. Stat.Annot, and cites in support of his possition Davis v. Utah, 151 U.S. 362, 38 L.Ed.155; Crane v. U.S. 162 U.S. 625. 40 L.Ed.1097; Howard v.U.S., 75 Fed.986; Ex parte Wilson, 114 U.S. 417.

Section 1028 R.S. referred to by counsel is an en-
actment of February 26, 1853, and reads as follows:

"(Copy of writ to be jailer's authority; original re- turned). Whenever a prisoner is committed to a sheriff or jailer by virtue of a writ, warrant, or mittimus, a copy thereof shall be delivered to such sheriff or jailer, as his authority to hold the prisoner, and the original writ, warrant, or mit- timus shall be returned to the proper court or officer, with the officer's return thereon."
All of the decisions referred to by counsel for peti- titioner and those cited herein, are decisions handed down since the enactment of the foregoing section.

Referring to the case of Davis v. Utah, supra, the Supreme Court considered the sufficiency of the indict- ment filed in the United States Court for the Territory of Utah. There is no question presented in this case of the sufficiency of the judgment or the commitment issued thereon. The sole question which is presented to the Supreme Court were questions having reference to the suf- ficiency of the indictment. The Supreme Court held the indictment good.

Reference to the case of Crane v. U.S., supra, shows that the question here presented is as to the sufficiency of the indictment. It was also contended in this case that the record should show that the defendant had entered a plea to the indictment. The Supreme Court conceded the importance, especially in a charge of murder, of arraign- ment and plea, and that due process of law requires that an accused person shall plead or be ordered to plead, or in a proper case that a plea of not guilty be filed for him be- fore his trial can rightfully proceed, and the record of his conviction should show distinctly and not by inference. It should appear affirmatively from the record that
every step necessary to the validity of the sentence has been taken in the trial court, otherwise the judgment will be erroneous.

It will be noted that counsel for the petitioner in this case has already stipulated, for it is un- doubtedly the fact, that all the essential and proper steps preceeding the entry of the judgment had been taken in the Thurston case.
reference to the stipulation shows that it is agreed by counsel that in cause no. 44-1, in which the judgment was entered, -

"An arraignment of the defendant Thomas L. Thurston was had, a plea of not guilty was entered by each of the defendants, and thereafter, in the same entit- led cause, a jury was empaneled and a verdict of guilty was rendered against the said defendants, and and numbered cause, a judgment was entered, a copy of which is attached to and made a part of the respondent's return herein."
It will thus be seen that the criticism which was made of the record of the court in the Crane case cannot be con- sidered as present in the case at bar.

Counsel cites for consideration of the court the case of Howard v. U.S. and Ex parte Wilson. It is respectfully suggested to the court that neither of these cases sustain the position of counsel, but seem to negative the con- tention made in behalf of the prisoner.

The Howard case, decided by the Circuit Court for the Sixith Circuit, quotes and discusses Section 1028 R.S. above quoted. It was there in two separate appeals urged upon the Circuit Court of Appeals that the commitment issued by the Clerk upon a conviction which charged several viola- tions in various counts, failed to include the phrase
"from date of" after the period of the first sentence, the judgment being a cumulative sentence on each of the several counts. The Circuit Court of Appeals states on page 989-

"The warrant or order of commitment is simply an authority and direction to the marshal to take the prisoner to the penitentiary named. The copy furnished by the marshal or clerk to the warden is merely evidence, and evidence only, of the judgment and sentence of the court and the mittimus issued thereunder.* * * The prisoner is not committed by virtue of the copy, but by virtue of the judgment of the court, and the mittimus issued pursuant thereto; the real valid authority under which the mittimus is issued being the sentence of the court."
The writ in the Howard case was denied.

Reference to the case of Ex parte Wilson, decided by the Supreme Court, Mr. Justice Gray delivering the opinion, divulges the faact that the prisoner therein raised the same contention as that made on behalf of the prisoner Thurston, to the effect that the-
"Keeper had no warrant or mittimus authorizing him to hold the prisoner, as required by Rev.Stat.1028."

The decision of the Supreme Court in the Wilson case, in my judgment, fully and definitely decided the first point above mentioned as being raised by counsel. It is ap- parent in the Wilson case that no mittimus was actually issued by the Clerk of the Court, there being used in- stead-
"A certified copy of the record of the sentence to imprisonment in the Detroit house of correction."
The Supreme Court dismissed the matter, in this short but definite phrase-

"The certified copy of the record. of the sentence to imprisonment in the Detention House of Correction, if valid upon its face, is sufficient to authorize the keeper to hold the prisoner, without any warrant or mittimus."
There is cited in support of that declaration-
People v. Nevins, 1 Hill (N.Y.) 154.
It will be noted that the Supreme Court has before it for consideration at this time Section 1028 referred to by counsel.
There is cited on behalf of the regpondent herein the following cases which are deemed as especially in point and decisive of the above contentions of counsel.
The attention of the court is first directed to Section 1035 of the Revised Statutes, page 340, volume 3 Fed. Stat.Annot.

"No indictment found and presented by a grand jury in any district or circuit or other court of the United States shall be deemed insufficient, nor shall the trial, judgment, or other proceedings thereon be affected by reason of any defect or imperfection in matter of form only, which shall not tend to the prejudice of the defendant."

It is respectfully suggested to the court that no fact is alleged in the petition and no suggestion has been made by counsel for the petitioner to the effect that the omission claimed in the second contention of counsel has in any manner whatsoever prejudiced the rights of the prisoner. If it should be conceded that the inclusion of some phrase referring to the crime of which the defendant is convicted were ordinarily essential in a criminal case, it would seem under the generally accepted weight to be given to Section 1025 that no criticism can be made of that fact if a record otherwise regular and unimpeachable exists
Since reference has been made by counsel to the necessity of certain allegations in the indictment, the attention of the Court is called to the statement in
Section 288, p. 314 of Joyce on Indictments-
"Although as a matter of form, it is said to be the better practice to name the offense in the indict- ment yet a failure to do so will not render it vulnerable to a demurrer or other objections.
State v. Baldy, 17 Iowa 39.
That authority further says-
"It was not required at the common law."
State v. Anderson, 3 Nev. 254
People v. Sullivan, 4 N.Y.Cr.C.193

These irregularities in the manner and form of the presentment of indictments have been found as immaterial in the face of some showing of prejudice on the part of the defendant. Failure to endorse "a true bill" is not a fatal defect. Frisbie v. U.S. 157 U.S. 160.

Recital in caption ofan indictment that the term of court was in the year "1885" where it should have been "1888" does not vitiate the indictment. Where the minutes, journals and other records show the grand jury impaneled in 1888.
United States v. Bornemann 35 Fed. 824.
The use of the term "Circuit Court of the United States" when in fact "District Court" was intended, does not vitiate the indictment.
Leddbetter v. U.S. 108 Fed. 52
Beebe v. U.S. 2 Dak. 292
The two cases which are deemed by counsel for the respondent a directly and finally in point and certainly decisive of defendants two contentions herein argued, are the cases of-
In the Pointer case-
The United States Supreme Court says:

"It is said that the record fails to show that all things were done in the court below before the sentence of death was pronounced, in this: First, the record nowhere states that the verdict was received and recorded; second, there is no record of anyjudgment declaring plaintiff in error to be guilty of murder."

The court sets out the order entered by the court in that case, which is in fact adjudgment of death against the defendant. Reference to the order or judgment shows that no where in this order or judgment was reference made to the crime for which he was convicted, but it is dis- tinctly and clearly told what disposition is to be made of the defendant Pointer.
The same objection was made there that is now made in this case, that is-
"That the sentence does not state the offense of which the defendant was found guilty, or that the defendant was found guilty or any named crime."
The Supreme Court says that this objection is technical rather than substaintial

The record in the trial preceeding the sentence shows an indictment returned into court by "a grand jury duly selected, impaneled, sworn and charged, etc." In other words, reference is here made by the Supreme Court to the record of the case other than the judgment as affording any light that might be necessary for the purpose of construing the order or judgment as entered.

The attention of the Court is further, directed to the White case above referred to, in which the same con- tention was made as set out in the second contention of the petitioner. The opinion of the Supreme Court in the White case recites at length the judgment of the court,
which omits, as in the Pointer case, all reference to the section or character of the crime charged against the defendant. The Supreme Court immediately after the quotation makes the following declaration:

"This we think was a sufficient judgment for all purposes. The record fully and substantially shows what the offense is of which the defendant was convicted, and the language used shows that the judgment was the sentence of the court and of the law pronounced upon the defendant on ac- count of the conviction on the indictment."
The Supreme Court cites the Pointer case in support of its position.
These two decisions seem clearly decisive of peti- tioner's two contentions.
If any further authorities are required they are to be found by reference to Section 995 (2) Criminal Law Volume 6 Dec.. The cases there cited include-
Talbert v. State, 37 So. 78, 140 Ala 96
Ex parte Doyle, 66 Pac. 949, 26 Nev. 281
Schirmacher v. State, 45 S.W. 802
Kiefel v. State, 94 S.W. 463, 49 Tex. 308
It is respectfully submitted under the foregoing decisions that the prayer of the petitioner should be de- nied.
Clay Allen United States Attorney and Attorney for Respondent.
IN THE DISTRICT COURT OF THE UNITED STATES FOR THE WESTERN DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON. Northern DIVISION.
In the Matter of the Petition of Thomas L. Thurston for a Writ of Habeas Corpus
MEMORANDUM BRIEF.
